Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Parylene-in-Parylene (PiP) integrated photonic systems for optogenetics in microelectrocorticography (uECoG)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Maharbiz, Michel
Proposal: 1512794

Implantable biophotonic devices are highly in demand for applications such as in-vivo sensing, imaging, and optogenetic neural stimulation. The researchers propose to design, fabricate, and characterize compact, flexible, and biocompatible photonic structures built entirely from Parylene. They will integrate such waveguides with switches and light sources to realize a fully reconfigurable and integrated photonic platform.


An all-Parylene photonic platform has never been published. Such an innovation would have immediate impact as Parylene is routinely used in ultra-flexible, implantable systems. Biocompatible and flexible integrated photonic structures are required that do not degrade, delaminate, or fall apart when used in chronic applications. Recent advances in flexible photonics mostly rely on transferring guided-wave devices to a flexible substrate to realize heterogeneous pseudo-flexible photonic devices. Such implementations are vulnerable to degradation and failure are only suitable for short-term diagnostic implants. The proposed research introduces a new platform for realizing compact and flexible integrated photonic devices leveraging an already well-developed biocompatible material system used for encapsulating biodevices. This program includes a well-conceived plan for outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative project, conducted by a team of researchers at the University of California, Berkeley and Carnegie Mellon University, demonstrated the design of a neural interface in the form of an ultrathin compliant surface patch that can be placed over the surface of the brain and under the skull for delivering precise patterns of light illumination for targeted optogenetic stimulation of the brain. This new brain interface will enable the design of next generation brain-machine interfaces.    

The advent of optogenetics, a method of using light to modulate neuronal activity in the brain, enabled interesting closed-loop experiments to understand brain function and dysfunction. However, practical application of optogenetics for chronic long-term experiments has been impeded by the lack of tools for efficient light delivery to the brain with high spatial resolution in a minimally invasive way. This project addressed this challenged head-on and demonstrated a new technological platform, as well as new microfabrication methods and tools.

A flexible neural patch that can record and stimulate brain simultaneously will help understand  brain function and dysfunction, informing the design of more efficient therapeutic interventions. Moreover, reliable and longer-lasting brain-machine interfaces can be designed based on the flexible neural interface developed under this grant.
